user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_prog:
```c
static int lfs_bd_prog(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    const uint8_t *data = buffer;
    LFS_ASSERT(block == LFS_BLOCK_INLINE || block < lfs->block_count);
    LFS_ASSERT(off + size <= lfs->cfg->block_size);

    while (size > 0) {
        if (block == pcache->block &&
                off >= pcache->off &&
                off < pcache->off + lfs->cfg->cache_size) {
            // already fits in pcache?
            lfs_size_t diff = lfs_min(size,
                    lfs->cfg->cache_size - (off-pcache->off));
            memcpy(&pcache->buffer[off-pcache->off], data, diff);

            data += diff;
            off += diff;
            size -= diff;

            pcache->size = lfs_max(pcache->size, off - pcache->off);
            if (pcache->size == lfs->cfg->cache_size) {
                // eagerly flush out pcache if we fill up
                int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
                if (err) {
                    return err;
                }
            }

            continue;
        }

        // pcache must have been flushed, either by programming and
        // entire block or manually flushing the pcache
        LFS_ASSERT(pcache->block == LFS_BLOCK_NULL);

        // prepare pcache, first condition can no longer fail
        pcache->block = block;
        pcache->off = lfs_aligndown(off, lfs->cfg->prog_size);
        pcache->size = 0;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_bd_prog:
#define LFS_BLOCK_NULL ((lfs_block_t)-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static int lfs_bd_prog(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
explanation: The other pointer uses in this function do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: - The parameter 'buffer' and the local 'data' are already const-qualified (const void *buffer and const uint8_t *data). - The pcache parameter and its members are written to (pcache->size, pcache->block, pcache->off, pcache->buffer via memcpy), so pcache must be a pointer to a non-const object. - The memcpy destination (&pcache->buffer[off-pcache->off]) is intentionally non-const because it is written to. - Local pointer arithmetic and temporary addresses (e.g. &pcache->buffer[...]) are used for mutation and therefore are not candidates for const qualification. No other pointer declarations or uses in the function are eligible for adding const without changing semantics, so they are not included as suspicious.
